What the video is dealing with has to do with imperfections in our biology related to perception. In my opinion, the video misses the real question. And that is, if our biology was perfect and there was no delay in perception, would we live only in a moment that we call "now"?

Here is a thought experiment. From the QM, we know that the distant ends of the universe are most likely entangled. That means any measurement (or observation) at one end of the universe has an instantaneous effect at the other end. This implies that perceptions occur at the same moment. Put in different words, it seems that the idealized NOW should be the same everywhere.

Note that, according to Einstein's theory of relativity, there is no way to determine if the NOW at one reference frame is the same as the NOW at another frame of reference.

Let's all ask - is the idealized NOW indeed the same everywhere? Why should NOW exist at all? I'd say these are much more interesting questions.

Funny how when my job has been video editing for over 30 years I noticed the delay immediately. As an editor over the years my brain has been tuned to notice 1 bad frame in 30 and then subsequently 1 frame in 60 and now even 1 in 120. I have been told that was impossible but have also proven it many times by catching bad frames at 120fps. The caveat to the initial assertion  is that the mind can learn to experience the “present” at higher frequency. It bears nothing that I am also a Zen Buddhist and have spent many hours practicing sitting or “meditation” and through that practice have, on a few rare occasions, experienced what I can only describe as absolute sentience; a feeling of the moment never coming or going but continuing endlessly. Much has been written about the concept of “flow” wherein a person engages in an activity that is almost “mindless”. Surfing, playing improvised music and even certain video games can allow a person to achieve this mindless experience where time itself seems to dissolve away and the observer can only recall a feeling they often have difficulty in communicating afterwards with language. The moment is apparently something our language riddled minds now have to struggle to truly experience. Even now trying to explain it here feels abysmally feeble and inadequate.

Mr Muller, I so love your videos. I wish that in this one you had covered the fact that there is no such thing as 'now'. All you have to do is ask the simple question: how long is 'now'? Because of the infinite nature of numbers, there can be no answer. Is 'now' a thousandth of a second? A millionth? A billionth? A billion billionth? It is like the classic problem of two objects never being able to touch. This is one of my most favorite subjects, and I think about it all the 'time'. Because time itself is an illusion. Since there is no such thing as 'now', there can be no such thing as 'time'. All that mankind has managed to do about the apparent existence of time is to get clocks all moving together, or more or less together, which is very convenient for when you want to meet somebody etc. But time is like gravity: an assumption with no basis in actual reality. What there is, is DURATION. Things continue in the same state - or give the illusion of continuing in the same state - and this gives the impression of something called 'time'. So then went and tried it at 0.25x, also tried following the circle, and frame by frame at the reduced speed, and am staring at the video paused at the spot and time in 4:05 where it supposedly appears. Probably an editing mistake, and those claiming they see it are bluffing.

Edit:
4:25 Ah... didn’t think he’d do it more, and was watching in 1.25x this time. Trying to make up lost time. But had to stop and update comment about this...

So this time I saw it every time it circled. First 2 looked normal, flash appeared in ring, ring moving at the same rate. Not surprising, given I can’t really see optical illusions. I’m not really sure this counts as an optical illusion though, because an optical illusion is an image telling a typical brain to do unusual things, while this is just pointing out a weird thing typical brains naturally do. So the tait(s) for these things are not necessarily codependent / related to the same gene.

When I’m trying to not miss something; like when I’m watching Veritasium; I’m replaying what I’m seeing in my head simultaneously so that I‘m half as likely to miss something. I didn’t feel like anything unexpected happened in real time on the 3rd time around, but in my memory instant replay the ring was 1/8 down from the 9 o’clock spot (7:30 o’clock) when I saw the flash, but the ring instantly teleported to be around the flash at the exact moment of flash, then it continued around from there. So I still saw the flash perfectly in the ring, and it happened so fast I chocked it up to misremembering (specifically; recalling out of order) rather than seeing wrong. I cold have found out for sure by just replaying the memory again, but I preferred to just keep watching in that moment.

The 4th time was undeniably crazy though. The ring was at 8 o’clock at the flash, but this time I saw the ring and the flash alone not touching for an instant, then the ring teleported to 10 o’clock still not touching the flash for an instant, then to 9 o’clock where it perfectly encompassed the flash. It was so fast that after the real time viewing I thought I might have seen 3 rings at once. But I slowed down the replay (and paused the video so the sync wouldn’t be off) and saw it appear like that. Then played it in reverse to rewatch the 3rd cycle, and it played out like in the first memory replay.

Edit 2:
His conclusion makes sense. Some peoples subconscious are probably just better or faster at interpreting the moment. Given enough cycles of the same thing my brain probably started getting lazy and assuming, and then it happened. And when my subconscious realized it made a mistake in showing the ring position relative to the flash too low it displayed it higher but over compensated the position offset by double before getting it right.

Many people have experienced time slowing down when they have been in high intensity moments and I often find that it is when people have a good understanding of the physics of what is happening to them. The brain can then somehow increase its frame rate to absorb more information about how the event occurred. For sportspeople, like racing drivers, this experience happens in real time and often. It is when they fully understand what is going on around them and are able to process the experience faster, it allows them to achieve almost super human feats. I'm not convinced by the specious present having to do with memory-formation. Your brain predicts the future to hide input/processing/output latency so you can for example put your hand in the right place to catch a ball. The reality you perceive is mostly based on inputs a fraction of a second old, and signals from motor neurons take time to reach muscles.

Most sensory-timing weirdness effects are an artifact of that sort of thing, like the circle-flash experiment. Causing mispredictions and examining the details of what happens are interesting ways to investigate the mechanism.

There are those who easily perceive the mismatch and those are professional online, sandbox and other types of digital gamers. The ping lag time(best under 10ms but noticeable after 75-125ms depending on experience), mouse and keyboard lag times(why do they always use a wired mouse and keyboard?) and other variables greatly impact a veteran's gameplay. While we are fine with the brain's autotune, professional gamers need as close to real time gameplay as possible. Gaming with satellite internet service vs land based Google fiber will have noticeably different video playbacks when recorded, that we as mere mortals may miss. The monitor they are seeing also needs to have a low lag time. A TV usually has a much higher lag time than a monitor. The TV needs to process much more information due to its versatility. A BenQ or Asus Rog monitor come to mind...........

Everything we see is light reflecting from a surface, this reflection takes time to hit our light receptors. So everything we are visually perceiving technically already happened.
Imagine you are receiving a baseball pitch. If you reacted to it at the time it took for the light to reflect from the baseball and travel to your eyes, and then for your brain to process the image on the back of the eyes, you would be way too late to hit the ball. Our brain has to make up for this lag and predict where the ball is GOING to be, not where it is.

When designing software, a general rule of thumb is that any response under 0.1s is perceived as instantaneous; anything longer is perceived by the user as there being a delay. So for example if you have a button that does some calculation and then displays a result, if the calculation is faster than 0.1s you don't need any additional considerations and can just put up the result whenever it's done, and the user will see it as being instant; if it takes longer than that, then displaying a loading/working mark, changing/disabling the button or some other method is required, otherwise the user is likely to press the button again, or at least be confused why there is no response.

To define the present in terms of the contents of the present is a fallacy.
Like defining a cup by the coffee it contains.
The coffee has nothing to do with the cup.
The present has nothing to do with the events that take place within it.
The present is a context, Without the context of the present, There would be no past or future events.
The context of the present is not an event but the container of all events.
The events that happen in the present in no way determine the present itself.
Like the fluid that fills a container in no way determines the ontology of the container itself.

As a life-long hobby film maker and professional musician/sound designer for image (didn't mean to hand out my CV :-) ), I know these things inside out. Often a sound needs to be shifted slightly in time to appear being in sync. The natural delay of sound of course doesn't apply to telephoto shots (where people are far away): the conversation needs to be in sync and not delayed - since our eyes are not telephoto lenses. Another interesting thing happens with artificial sounds which are not short claps or clicks, but rather impacts or punches. Sometimes these need to start just a little early (not late!). Last thought: one sound might appear fully in sync when you just watch the short scene - now start the video earlier and watch in context - it might be slightly off again. Very likely expectations and brain mechanisms. Thanks for reading and thanks for another great video!

Derek, Please give me your thoughts on this. -
As I see it (not literally but figuratively). When the brain is processing information. It is often processing it in ways that are for the best part, conserving. Like a computer, the brain does not have truly unlimited storage. Granted, it has a lot, but not unlimited. As such, much of what we experience through our senses is identified and organized to integrate this factor. When we see something that is even remotely repetitive, our own brain is organizing the information as it comes to us in such a way that, it is hypothesizing that the action will behave as expected even if we consciously are expecting otherwise.

A line that is going across the screen will be assumed to continue to go across the screen. Consciously we may be thinking, "ok, it's going to stop or something", but our brains internal processes are already working on it continuing. Additionally, most of us grow up not being attuned to consciously taking note of a subtle or minor deviation to the expected. As children we might, but as adults, our brain has seen enough that it can now build its own hypothesis as to what is coming. Even if something is moving forward yet moving all over the place (squiggle), the brain is still evaluating it such that, it expects the object to continue to move forward.

This to me is also due to the fact that we follow the laws of physics in everyday life and as such, mentally expect the results we often see. A ball falls, we expect it to fall to the ground, not stop half way and then go up like a Yoyo. As such, our own brain may very well finish that decent and ascent with only a possibility of noticing it did not go all the way down due to a lack of sound. Because of natural expectation, if the ball were to fall part of the way yet emit a sound as if it hit the ground and then come up. The person would very likely not notice it did not go all the way down and instead, assume it was just quicker than expected in its return. The reality is, our brains are trying to save room and, as such, memories, thoughts and events are calculated and evaluated in search of saving that space. A change in the environment means more processing time, more processing power, more memory, etc. A fraction of a second of sound vs visual input in many cases does not give the brain a need to process more. Noticing something out of the center of ones vision contributes to a similar effect.

In the end, its all about conservation of resources. After all, when we get old, who knows how much stuff we WON'T remember. Hmmmm....food for thought?

So what I learned is that our brain lags. Our sensory system receives information, but doesn't just forward it to our consciousness but instead crosschecks it with other information from different areas of our sensory system, tries to synchronize them and computes them to the impression of reality that we perceive, resulting in a false image of reality that most of the time has the advantage of being easier to comprehend.

So optical illusions are bugs in or demonstrations of the rules the brain uses to sync and compute information from the sensory system.

There's actually a nice demontration of your last statement in computer science. When parsing a text, and turning it into gramatically structured information (like making computer code into a program, or parsing some parts of human language into nouns and verbs and so on), it turns out only the simplest grammars can be parsed one letter at a time. The moment your grammar grows the least bit complex, you need predictive power of a portion of the local future to decide how to interpret the current symbol. You don't know if "s" starts a noun or a verb until you've read the entire word. So you need to delay that choice, and look ahead in the text, to find that future information you need. That's sort of what our brains are doing here, right? Delaying the interpretation of the present until a bit into the future where it has more info to base it on. It almost sounds self-evident we'd evolve to work like that.

The Specious Present- sounds nice but it's just a pretenscious way of saying, now. Now, is a great word! It's short, and easy to say, even babies learn it quickly, the word, "now" has a lot going for it. The only problem "now" has is that everyone already knows how slippery it is. If you come at "now" from almost any physical or metaphysical way, it's tricky to pin down and you're often taking a trip down a rabbit hole. Realizing that now is a complex amalgamation of a little while ago, simply because we're made of meat and slow wiring doesn't diminish... now. It expands our world, the way science always does, and gives "now" a fascination and gravitas it didn't have before. Renaming "now" as "The Specious Present" is nothing more than a pretenscious dickhead ( the OG, not you ), trying to sound smart.
But really, I think you should've included your buddy over at Vsauce in the thanks at the end. It was solid work on your part though.

I noticed it immediately too. But then, I use to some video editing so I'm always careful about things like that. Also, wireless controller for things like smash bros. has a slight delay that really gets to me. But I think all this might be missing a larger point. Try this experiment if you're near sighted. Play a FPS or a racing game on a big screen a good distance away so things are just slightly blurry (my game of choice was splatoon and mario kart) and measure your reaction time. Now do it with your glasses on. If you're like me, you'll see that your reaction is slowed. But it's because you're spending more time trying to figure out what is what/where. In computer programming, there's a whole field of study about image recognition and in it, we find that to do things like recognizing things in a flat image is hard and very work intensive. We often think this is easy because the human brain doesn't even need to stop and look at every pixel to recognize a certain object. But the truth is, we do. We just do it very quickly. But as the image gets more fuzzy or noisy, you'll find that computer image recognition, and our own, takes longer. This is the same for figuring out things like sound synching between audio and video. While we're looking at an image and processing it, there's a gap of time where we're spending analyzing the image and not seeing the next image. Now, that's not to say we can't mess with our own internal clocks through training or conditioning, but this is, in my experience with animation, a better explanation than our brains trying to expect something. This explanation would also explain things like how humans can miss the forest for the trees when someone focuses on 1 aspect of a sight and miss things going around it.

Oh, and although some people don't notice it consciously, they do notice it consciously. When the sound of a video or animation lags by a few milliseconds, although a person might not notice that that's what's happening, they'll generally feel that the same video/animation is moving "at a slower pace" (as in the pacing of a story or the film as a whole.) than one that's synched up.

Most of the calculations of the brain include a variation of the Fourier transform.
We observe the world in what is called FFT. It is a timeless frequency space of short time intervals.
This is most evident on how we perceive sound. We do not hear sound as it actually is, rather, we perform some form of an FFT in order to hear the frequencies present in a time interval.

This could be related to the Theory of 'Stew'. Once a grouping of individual ingredients reaches a given number (4 in most cultures), and is cooked within water, the concoction becomes a generic stew regardless of the ingredients. The ingredients do not change, but we generalize the complexity into a simpler factor to consider. This manner of thinking about mundane matters saves energy and reduces mental taxation. In contrast, when subject matter is too complex to generalize and must remain detailed in every nuance of consideration they very act of complex thought can be exhausting.

Really interesting concept covered here. I noticed that there seems to be a parallel between this specious present we experience and the difficulties we have defining 'instantaneous velocity'.   Specifically, while many are interested in the concept of a knowing what velocity objects are moving at an instant in time, velocity itself is defined over two points (both in time and space) between which displacement occurs.  So, while we can make these two points as close together as a instruments can capture, it will never really be a 'single instant'. It can be argued then that motion itself (which is necessary for all life) can only be considered over a period... like the specious present.

I feel like the experiment is flawed. Either Veritasim or Vsauce did a video about why movies don't appear jerky (like stop-motion) even though they are played at a very slow frame rate. It's because bright images on dark back drops linger a bit because of how they excite our receptor cells and they have to "cool off". In other words, a bright object flashing very quickly will appear to be a more continuous than it really is. It's like how when you look at a light bulb then close your eyes you still perceive a bright spot.

Because of this, it could simply be the case that we continue to perceive the white spot at exactly the 6 o'clock position longer than it is actually there. Thus it appears at that spot while the green ring has moved to a new position and the flash appears correspondingly above or below. Our receptor cells perhaps have not fully recovered and are still somewhat exited by a bright flash on a dark background (and they still "see" the white flash).

Another good experiment to demonstrate this is to quickly look at a mechanical clock. Look somewhere else and then quickly look over and stare at it. If you catch it just right then it will appear as though the second hand stays in place longer than a second. The reason for this is your brain can't decide what to report during the transition so it doesn't report anything until you stop moving your eyes, and so what you finally see is the second hand and that is what your brain reports for occurring in the past and so it looks as though it has been there longer than a second.

If we define specious present by the brain's need to examine additional (even post-event) information to better comprehend what happens/happened, we then must take into account that it is not only visual information that we perceive. We use all our senses including performing involuntary small moves to make sure we have a clear reference system of coordinates and a better understanding of not only the position but all its derivatives (speed, acceleration...) of the object we watch. This is perhaps why when you try to frame the present in a picture almost always it fails to give the same "sense" you had when you were taking this picture...

I FEEL LIKE THERE IS A BIG PROBLEM WITH THE SPACE KEY EXPERIMENT. There are too many variables. It is important to note if the key is of a mechanical keyboard or mesh/electronic keyboard. It looks like you start the time as soon as the key begins to be pushed, which makes me think that it is a mechanical keyboard. Most people are used to mesh keyboards which requires someone to push the key virtually all the way down to read that the key has been pressed. Also people often preceive a full press of a button as a push AND release. Therefore, they are associating the press as when they push and release the key, that amount of time takes nearly a tenth of a second which essentially makes it seem completely synconized to them with the full press and release. When you make the green light comes up instantly (which i assume as been program to appear on the down press), they feel that the green light comes up before the press becuase 1. they are not likely used to a mechanical keyboard, which registers an input with much less depression. 2) they are likely assuming that a press is a full press AND release. I am not saying that the phenomenon you are testing doesnt exist. I am saying the experiment is flawed or more explanation is required.

There are a few other neat effects around this 'buffering' that the brain performs. If you tap your toe and the top of your head simultaneously, you perceive both at the same time, even though it takes about 80ms longer (on average, and depending on your height) for the signal to travel from your toe. Your brain buffers the signals and presents them to your conscious experience of the event,s as simultaneous. Your vision is also buffered to avoid presenting the blurred mess of information, as your eyes move rapidly from one scene to another. When you look away from your computer, to check the clock, your brain ignores the blur as your eyes sweep across the room. In order to make this work, the brain shows you the first stable glance at the clock for an extra 80ms, while it clears the buffer of blurred information. If you do it a few times, you may see that the second hand appears to stop, for a moment, before resuming its regular tick-tick-tick. You can find all sorts of interesting phenomena (as well as scholarly papers on the subject) by Googling "80ms in the past".

Hey Derek, Great video, very insightful. There are tho things you mentioned I do not completely agree yet:

1) The test of David Eagleman clearly Eliminate the hypothesis that our brain predicts where the green cycle would be, yet I'm not sure yet that this effect is caused by a processing delay. It can be caused by the refresh rate of the retina. we all know that when we see a flash of light, it takes few milliseconds for it to be erased from sight. So we might see the "past" white circle inside the "present" green circle. Do you have in mind any method to verify it?

2) While the specious present is a collection of sensory perceptions stretching over a tiny period of time, I think we experience them all in the present moment. That is, it takes some time for our senses and brain to process the information into a mental image, and it combines things that might have happened in various moments, but experiencing that mental image happens in the present.
